questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic renal failure is admitted to the ICU. His prolonged hospitalization has led to malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies. Which of the following is used for the functional assessment of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC transketolase         

 

Option C:

 

  • Thiamine nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.
  • The activation of apo-transketolase (the enzyme protein) in erythrocyte lysate by thiamin diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamin nutritional status.
  • In thiamine deficiency, blood levels of thiamine are reduced with increase in pyruvate, alpha ketoglutarate, and lactate.
  • Also Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced which is the earliest manifestation before the clinical manifestations sets in.
  • Erythrocyte transketolase levels are also reduced in other conditions like comatose patients, alcoholics, chronic renal failure, malnutrition, patients in ICU as well as in elderly patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum thiamine levels: In thiamine deficiency, though the blood thiamine levels are reduced, reduction in erythrocyte transketolase activity is the earliest manifestation seen before the appearance of clinical manifestations.

 

Option B. RBC glutathione peroxidase and Option D. RBC glutathione reductase: Glutathione is present in RBCs, used for inactivation of free radicals that is formed inside RBC with the help of a selenium containing enzyme glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and the glutathione is regenerated by glutathione reductase (GR), an NADPH dependent enzyme. (NADPH is derived from GPD shunt pathway and its deficiency attributes to hemolysis and impairment of regeneration of reduced glutathione)

 

Educational objective:

 

The functional assessment of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency is typically done using the RBC transketolase activity assay. An increase in the enzyme's activity upon the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) indicates a deficiency in thiamine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 556 , Lippincott 7/e : P 379

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the activity of various enzymes in the pentose phosphate pathway. In assessing the enzyme transketolase, the biochemist considers which coenzyme is essential for its catalytic action. Identify the coenzyme that is required by the transketolase enzyme.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)

 

Option B:

 

  • The coenzyme form of Thiamine is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) which is essential for PDH, transketolase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP): Acts as Coenzyme in transamination and decarboxylation of amino acids and glycogen phosphorylases.

 

Option C. Coenzyme A: Acts as an important component of fatty acid synthase complex, acyl groups are accepted by CoA molecules during the metabolism of other substrates etc.

 

Option D. Biotin: Coenzyme for carboxylation reactions - Propionyl CoA Carboxylase, Acetyl CoA Carboxylase and Pyruvate Carboxylase.

 

Educational objective:

 

Transketolase is an enzyme that plays a critical role in the pentose phosphate pathway, a metabolic pathway parallel to glycolysis. It requires Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine), as a coenzyme for its activity.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 550,556 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 478

questions.text: A clinical instructor is discussing the biochemistry of metabolism with a medical student during a case review of a patient suspected of having a nutritional deficiency. The instructor asks the student to identify which reaction within the citric acid cycle requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a coenzyme.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Œ±‚Äìketoglutarate -> Succinyl CoA

 

The conversion of Œ±-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA is catalyzed by the Œ±-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, which is a multi-enzyme system requiring several coenzymes:
 

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) ‚Äî derived from vitamin B1
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A (CoA)
  • NAD‚Å∫
  • FAD
     

TPP functions in decarboxylation of Œ±-keto acids, making it essential for this reaction and also for the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex and branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase.
 

NOTE: B1 is Co- factor for oxidative Decarboxylation of Alpha Keto Acid
 

Example:

  • PDH
  • Œ± Ketoglutarate DH
  • Branched chain Œ± Keto acid DH
     

Isocitrate Dehydrogenase also do oxidative Decarboxylation but isocitrate is not Keto acid so B1 is not Co-factor for this Enzyme.

 

Option A. Citrate -> Œ±-ketoglutarate: This conversion actually involves two separate reactions:

  1. Citrate -> Isocitrate (catalyzed by aconitase, which requires Fe-S cluster)
  2. Isocitrate -> Œ±-ketoglutarate (catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase, which requires NAD+ or NADP+) As this reaction is also example of oxidative 

 

Decarboxylation but isocitrate is not Keto acid so B1 is not Co-factor for this reaction.
 

Neither of these steps requires TPP.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Succinyl CoA -> Succinate: This reaction is catalyzed by succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase), which requires GDP/ADP and inorganic phosphate as substrates, generating GTP/ATP. No TPP is required for this reaction.
 

Option C. Œ±‚Äìketoglutarate -> Succinyl CoA: Correct - As explained above, this reaction requires TPP as a coenzyme for the decarboxylation step in the Œ±-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex.
 

Option D. Acetyl CoA -> Citrate: This reaction is catalyzed by citrate synthase, which condenses acetyl CoA with oxaloacetate to form citrate. This reaction does not require TPP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the active form of vitamin B1, is a crucial coenzyme in Oxidative decarboxylation of Alpha Keto Acid. In the citric acid cycle, TPP is specifically required for the Œ±-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex, which catalyzes the conversion of Œ±-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA. This is mechanistically similar to the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA), which also requires TPP. Thiamine deficiency can therefore impair these critical energy-producing pathways, contributing to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.
 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 555-556; Vasudevan 7/e: 477-478.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of alcoholism is admitted to the emergency room exhibiting global confusion, ataxia, and psychosis. On examination, he is found to have ophthalmoplegia and polyneuropathy. Which vitamin should be administered urgently as part of his treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiamine. 

 

Option C:

 

  • The patient is presenting with the signs and symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy- consists of the classic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and global confusion, which is a medical emergency necessitates immediate administration of thiamine or vitamin B1.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Niacin is converted to nicotinamide → incorporated into the coenzymes NAD+ and NADP+.  Pellagra, a condition associated with niacin deficiency, leads to diarrhoea, dermatitis, and dementia.

 

Option B. Pyridoxine is utilized as the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate.  A deficiency in pyridoxine can lead to peripheral neuropathy and dermatitis.

 

Option D. Riboflavin is responsible for maintaining proper levels of both FMN and FAD.  Individuals with riboflavin deficiency present with lesions of the lips, mouth, skin, and genitalia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, a medical emergency often associated with chronic alcoholism that is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Treatment requires the immediate administration of thiamine, which can prevent the progression to Korsakoff syndrome, a chronic and debilitating condition.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 555-556.

questions.text: A 22-year-old homeless male with signs of alcohol intoxication presents to the emergency room exhibiting psychotic symptoms. Considering the acute management of such a patient, which compound is crucial to administer first?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine

 

Option D:

 

  • Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine deficiency, which play a role in the incoordination (ataxia) and psychosis that can become chronic (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome).
  • The thiamine deficiency produces relative deficiency of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glucose:  The administration of glucose without checking its levels can cause excess glucose to get converted to pyruvate by glycolysis. The low rate of pyruvate dehydrogenase conversion of pyruvate to coenzyme A (and entry into TCA cycle) causes pyruvate to be converted to lactate. Lactic acidosis can be fatal.

 

Option B. Niacin and C: Nicotinic acid: Chronic alcoholics can be deficient in the other vitamins mentioned, but thiamine is most likely to help the neurologic symptoms.

 

Educational objective:

 

Administering thiamine is essential in patients with alcohol intoxication who present with neurological symptoms, to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious condition associated with thiamine deficiency often seen in chronic alcohol users. Thiamine should be given before any glucose-containing solutions to avoid precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 478

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a long history of alcohol abuse is evaluated for symptoms including muscle weakness, forgetfulness, loss of appetite, hand tremors, involuntary eye movements, an unsteady gait, fine tremors, and mental confusion. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke-Korsakoff Psychosis

 

Option A:

 

  • C/F: Encephalopathy + ophthalmoplegia + nystagmus + cerebellar ataxia + psychosis. Seen in severe nutritional deficiency.
  • Polyneuritis is common in chronic alcoholics.
  • Alcohol utilization requires large doses of thiamine; hence it inhibits intestinal absorption of thiamine leading to thiamine deficiency.
  • Deficiency causes impairment of conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA ü°™ increased plasma concentration of pyruvate and lactate ü°™ lactic acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dry beriberi: Here CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbance resulting in complete paralysis occurs.

 

Option C. Wet beriberi: Here CVS manifestations are prominent present as edema of legs, face, trunk and serous cavities and palpitation, breathlessness and distended neck veins. Finally, death occurs due to heart failure.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Includes Megaloblastic anemia, Homocystinuria, Demyelination, Subacute combined degeneration and Achlorhydria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and a long-standing history of alcohol abuse points toward Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. This syndrome is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to poor nutritional intake and absorption.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 478.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of chronic alcohol use and poor appetite is hospitalized with symptoms of "high output" cardiac failure. Given his background and clinical presentation, which enzyme is most likely to be inhibited due to a deficiency associated with his lifestyle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Option B:

 

  • This patient’s symptoms are suggestive of beriberi heart disease, due to nutritional deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • The active form of the vitamin B1, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), is a required cofactor for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
  • In the TCA cycle, Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase catalysing reaction requires TPP, which causes oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2.
  • Transketolase and Pyruvate dehydrogenase also use thiamine as coenzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aconitase: In TCA cycle, citrate is isomerized to isocitrate by aconitase in a two-step process. At first, one water molecule is removed to form cis aconitate and one water molecule is added to form isocitrate (No cofactor is required in this step).

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form alpha ketoglutarate with NADH generated and one molecule of CO2 is liberated.

 

Option D. Citrate synthase: Oxaloacetate condenses with acetyl CoA to form citrate. None of the above 3 enzymes requires ‘Thiamine’ as cofactor.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency due to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption. The enzyme α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, a thiamine-dependent enzyme in the citric acid cycle, requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a cofactor. Inhibition of this enzyme can lead to energy metabolism impairment and may contribute to cardiac dysfunction.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 555-556; Vasudevan 7/e: 477-478.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy who is homeless presents with lethargy, irritability, poor appetite, and bilateral pitting pedal edema. His diet is primarily composed of polished rice, lacking fresh fruits and vegetables. On examination, elevated blood lactic acid is noted, and X-ray findings include cardiomegaly with pleural effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wet beriberi

 

Option B:

 

The child is fed with polished rice and has features of wet beriberi.

 

  • Deficiency of thiamine causes beriberi present as anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness and weakness.
  • Wet beriberi: Here CVS manifestations are prominent present as edema of legs, face, trunk and serous cavities and palpitation, breathlessness and distended neck veins. Finally, death occurs due to heart failure.
  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (whole wheat flour and unpolished hand pound rice) is rich in thiamine. When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed causing thiamine deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dry beriberi: Here CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbance resulting in complete paralysis occurs.

 

Option C. Infantile beriberi: Seen in infants born to mothers suffering from thiamine deficiency. C/F: Restlessness and sleeplessness.

 

Option D. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome/Cerebral beriberi: C/F: Encephalopathy + ophthalmoplegia + nystagmus + cerebellar ataxia + psychosis. Seen in severe nutritional deficiency.

 

Educational objective:

 

Wet beriberi is characterized by cardiovascular symptoms, including cardiomegaly, edema, and pleural effusion, which are consistent with the findings in this case. It is associated with a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), which is commonly seen in diets that consist mainly of polished rice, as the milling process removes the thiamine-rich outer layers of the grains.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 478.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with signs of metabolic acidosis, the medical team considers a potential link to nutritional deficiencies. Which vitamin deficiency is known to lead to lactic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Option B:

 

  • Thiamine deficiency affects Pyruvate Dehydrogenase and causes lactic acidosis.
  • Its deficiency in alcoholism may cause impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA → result in increased plasma concentration of pyruvate and lactate → lactic acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Riboflavin: Deficiency can disrupt normal cellular function but is not commonly associated with lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Niacin: While crucial for many metabolic processes, niacin deficiency typically leads to pellagra, not directly to lactic acidosis.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: A component of coenzyme A and important for fatty acid synthesis and energy production, its deficiency is rare and not typically linked with lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can result in lactic acidosis due to its role as a coenzyme in the metabolism of pyruvate. This condition emphasizes the importance of thiamine in carbohydrate metabolism and the potential for metabolic acidosis when this process is impaired.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 478.
